title: Earl Stewart
text:
Earl Richard Stewart Jr. (October 15, 1921 – July 11, 1990) was an American <a href="professional%20golfer">professional golfer</a> who played on the <a href="PGA%20Tour">PGA Tour</a> in the 1950s and 1960s; and was a college head golf coach in the 1970s and 1980s.
Stewart was born in <a href="Dallas%2C%20Texas">Dallas, Texas</a>. He graduated from Dallas' <a href="Sunset%20High%20School%20%28Texas%29">Sunset High School</a> in 1938. He attended <a href="Louisiana%20State%20University">Louisiana State University</a> and was a member of the <a href="golf">golf</a> team. In 1941, he won the <a href="NCAA%20Division%20I%20Men%27s%20Golf%20Championships">NCAA Championship</a>, and led the <a href="LSU%20Tigers">Bayou Bengals</a> to a share of the NCAA team title in 1942. He is a Member of the Sunset High School Hall of Fame.
Stewart had three wins in PGA Tour events during his career. His first win came in 1953 at the <a href="Greater%20Greensboro%20Open">Greater Greensboro Open</a>. He would win the <a href="Ardmore%20Open">Ardmore Open</a> later that year. His best finishes in <a href="Men%27s%20major%20golf%20championships">major championships</a> were T10 at the 1952 <a href="U.S.%20Open%20%28golf%29">U.S. Open</a> and T16 at <a href="Masters%20Tournament">The Masters</a> in 1953. Like many professional golfers of his generation, Stewart earned his living primarily as a club pro. His third and final win on the PGA Tour, the 1961 <a href="Dallas%20Open%20Invitational">Dallas Open Invitational</a>, came on his own course at the Oak Cliff Country Club.
Stewart was the head golf coach at <a href="Southern%20Methodist%20University">Southern Methodist University</a> from 1975–1987. He coached both the men's and women's teams. Men's golf was dropped by the university in 1980. He won a national championship with the women's team in 1979. One of his students was future two-time <a href="U.S.%20Open%20%28golf%29">U.S. Open</a> and <a href="PGA%20Championship">PGA Champion</a> <a href="Payne%20Stewart">Payne Stewart</a> (no relation). In 1987, he was inducted into the National Golf Coaches Association Coaches Hall of Fame for his role as a women's collegiate golf coach at SMU.
Stewart died after a long illness at the age of 68 at his home in <a href="Quitman%2C%20Texas">Quitman, Texas</a>.
Professional wins (4).
PGA Tour wins (3).
PGA Tour playoff record (1–2)
